newsitem.title: USA: KPMG sues exiting partners, seeks arbitration.
newsitem.headline: KPMG sues exiting partners, seeks arbitration.

text.p: KPMG Peat Marwick LLP has sued four partners who resigned recently according to papers filed late Monday in the Delaware Chancery Court.
The suit was filed simultaneously with a related demand for arbitration on the partnership dispute.

KPMG alleges the partners are violating the terms of their partnership agreement by soliciting other KPMG partners and employees to join in a new competitive venture and raising capital to finance it.
"Defendants have announced their intention to create a consulting business in direct competition with KPMG...(and) have been securing capital and financing," court papers say.
Named as defendants are Ted Fernandez, Ulysses Knotts, and Allan Frank, who resigned Jan 28 and stated their intention of opening a consulting business; and David Dungan who resigned Feb 20.
KPMG said the partners' resignations are not effective until six months after being submitted and that for two years they must comply with certain non-compete provisions.
KPMG also seeks reimbursement from the partners for "the full amount of capital and the full value of resources that KPMG invested in order to develop the consulting practice."
Dungan could not be reached for comment. A spokeswoman for the other three partners said "they denied the allegations" of the lawsuit.
